title-group.subtitle: A Structural Approach to the Comparative Study of Institutional Meaning Systems

article-meta.aff: 1 E. J. Ourso College of Business, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Thomas Greckhamer, E. J. Ourso College of Business, Louisiana State University, 3173B, Patrick Taylor Hall, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, USA Email: tgreck@lsu.edu

abstract.p: Advancing methodological approaches to the comparative study of institutional meaning systems is vital for institutional analysis in a globalizing world where cultural resources such as concepts and models of organization circulate across institutional fields. This article illustrates a structural approach to the comparative study of local meanings of global concepts. It demonstrates the use of semantic network analysis (SNA) as a suitable methodological approach to study local meaning structures across nations and institutional fields, by investigating the relationship between institutional logics and local meanings of the industry cluster concept in public discourse in eight countries. The article concludes with recommendations for further applications of SNA to research on institutional meaning systems.

body.p: While cultural materials such as keywords denoting concepts and models of organization are increasingly available globally (Drori et al. 2006; Meyer 2000), local social orders or institutional fields (Beckert 2010; DiMaggio and Powell 1983; Fligstein 2001) provide and shape the range of their sociocultural connotations (Czarniawska and Sevón 1996; Kroeber 1940). These local social orders are constituted and governed by socially (re)produced collective meaning systems permeated by institutional logics (Lounsbury 2007; W. R. Scott 1994; Whitley 1999). Thus, advancing methodological approaches to the comparative study of institutional meaning systems is vital for institutional analysis in a globalizing world.

This article contributes to filling this need for methodological advances by presenting a structural approach to map, represent, interpret, and compare institutional meaning systems that are enacted through discourse—collections of meaningful texts that construct objects (Phillips et al. 2004). Structural approaches provide an appropriate theoretical foundation to map and interpret meanings of texts. They seek meaning through identification of systematic patterns in cultural codes; these patterns of relationships among cultural symbols such as words constitute meaning (Bernard and Ryan 1998; Carley 1993; Mohr 1998). Thus, meaning can be found in associations among words constituting a system of signs (langue), which is the instrument and product of instances of speech or writing (parole; Saussure 1959). Identifying and interpreting structural meaning is accomplished by analyzing relations among concepts represented by words.

Applying this approach to investigate local meanings of global concepts, I illustrate a comparative research design for creating and analyzing networks of structural meaning in the context1 of a specific keyword (Williams 1985) through semantic network analysis (SNA) (Carley 1993, 1994, 1997) to study, map, and compare structural properties of texts. SNA focuses on patterns of relationships and is simultaneously quantitative and qualitative (Bernard 2005; Danowski 1993). Consistent with structuralism, its premise is that meaning of texts lies in the patterns of relations among concepts (Bernard and Ryan 1998; Carley 1993, 1997).

In the following sections, I illustrate the utility of this approach to map, analyze, and compare institutional meaning structures through a comparative study of various local meanings attached to a global concept and discuss the implications of using SNA to investigate meanings.

sec.title: Applying SNA to Comparative Analyses of Institutional Meaning Systems
sec.p: For illustration purposes, I chose to study the meanings attached to the concept industry cluster. Industry clusters, defined as “geographic concentrations of interconnected companies and institutions in a particular field” (Porter 1990:78), represent a model of organizing economic activities; the concept has become prevalent in economic development discourse in many countries. Policy makers around the world have been captivated by industry clusters’ assumed potential to increase their respective region’s prosperity, and the industry cluster concept has become the basis for economic development policy in many countries and regions (McCann and Folta 2008; Porter 1998, 2000).2 To illustrate the utility of semantic networks as tools to represent and interpret meaning structures in institutional fields, I: (1) map local meanings of the industry cluster concept onto semantic networks; (2) explore relationships between local meaning structures and associated institutional logics; and (3) explore the kinds of local meanings of the concept associated with these logics.

Local social orders are shaped by institutional logics—cultural beliefs and norms that construct and shape the rules of the economic game as well as the cognitions of economic actors and their repertoires of actions (Lounsbury 2007; W. R. Scott 1994; Whitley 1999). Nation-states have developed distinct logics for governing economies (Campbell and Lindberg 1990; Dobbin 1994b). Moreover, national institutions share similarities in overall regimes—institutionalized social orders of governance (Hollingsworth and Streeck 1994; W. R. Scott and Meyer 1991). Jepperson (2002; Jepperson and Meyer 1991) identified four ideal-typical institutional regimes, capturing distinct logics of organizing: liberal, state–corporate, state–nation, and social–corporate. This study focuses on countries representing the opposing ideal types state–corporate and liberal institutional regimes.

Data were collected from eight nations, spanning two language groups and variations of two institutional regimes: Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, the United States; and Austria, Germany, and Switzerland. The first five represent liberal regimes, whereas the last three represent state–corporate regimes (Jepperson 2000, 2002; Jepperson and Meyer 1991; Streeck and Schmitter 1985). Data were drawn from each country’s popular news media articles because they are important production sites of business discourse, construct and transmit its meaning to broad audiences, and can draw widespread attention to particular concepts (Fourcade-Gourinchas and Babb 2002; Mazza and Alvarez 2000). The universe of relevant articles is defined as all articles mentioning “industry cluster” or its variants3 published in one of the studied countries in 1990–2005. I retrieved available data from the Factiva database and screened it manually to remove articles referring to kinds of clusters other than industry clusters or those not published in the studied countries, resulting in a final data set of 3,776 articles. To study the keyword’s meaning in context, I extracted each mention of cluster(s) within its immediate textual context of 500 characters (Gephart 1993; Krippendorf 1980), resulting in 11,629 keyword-in-context data units (see Table 1 for distribution of data across countries).

caption.p: Articles and KWIC Data Units by Country

sec.title: Mapping Textual Meaning onto Semantic Networks
sec.p: The initial step in this research design was to map the local meanings of the selected concept onto semantic networks (Carley 1993, 1997). A network consists of nodes (here, concepts) connected through ties (here, relations among concepts defined by co-occurrence), and values of strength for each connection (here, frequency of co-occurrence; Wassermann and Faust 1994). I utilized both theoretical understanding of the studied phenomenon and induction from the data to define the concepts of the network (Ryan and Bernard 2003).

Three discursive elements are theoretically important in logics of organizing economic activity: actors, actions, and objects of action (DiMaggio and Mullen 2000). This framework, supported by literature on industry clusters, provided the basis for a theory-driven iterative process of identifying concepts; these constituted the categories into which words occurring in textual data were classified (see Table 2) (Carley 1993; Krippendorf 1980; Miles and Huberman 1994). After reading articles in the data set and generating word frequency lists for countries’ keyword-in-context data sets (Carley and Palmquist 1992; Schnegg and Bernard 1996), appropriate concepts in which to assign the most salient and frequent words emerged from theory and data. This process included iterations of identifying concepts and assigning words into concepts, up to a point of saturation, when no new concepts were needed to accommodate salient words (Strauss and Corbin 1998). During this process, I developed two matching thesauruses, relating words and concepts, relying primarily on established semantic categorization schemes for German (Deichsel 1975; Dornseiff and Quasthoff 2004; Universität Leipzig n.d.) and English (Levin 1993; Webster’s 1998).

tr.td: Economic development agency, regional development agency
Low tech, low technology, dairy industry

fn.p: Note. Country-specific examples are given for the United States.

sec.p: Specifically, I coded names of actors (individuals and organizations) into actor concepts government, consultant, economic development agency, interest group, corporation, and university. For instance, names of government representatives or offices were coded as government, consultants or consulting firms were coded as consultant. Action concepts covering action-related words emerging from the data were taken from the aforementioned established semantic categorization schemes of verbs.

Selection of concepts representing important objects of action of this discourse had various motivations. First, I coded industries mentioned in the data into hightech or lowtech (following Hecker 1999). Second, I included the concepts nation, region, and city, to investigate whether geographic units of interest in the discourse differ across countries. Third, I coded all references to foreign geographical areas as international to capture emphasis on international versus national locations. Fourth, I included the concepts cooperation, relationship, and competition, to capture ways of relating, as important aspects of organizing economic activity (North 1990). Fifth, I included the concepts plan–strategy and development as references to rationalized cultural objects of plans and strategies and the rationalized idea of economic development (Dobbin 1994a). Sixth, I included the concept public to explore the inclusion of society.

To capture evaluative aspects of meaning, I included positive and negative evaluative concepts. After reviewing valence categories in Deichsel (1975) and the Harvard IV Dictionary, I selected antonymous concepts that were salient in the data: good–bad, important–unimportant, advantage(ous)–disadvantage(ous), new–old, and success(ful)(ness)–unsuccess(ful)(ness).

This process resulted in an initial set of 71 concepts. Following previous literature (Danowski 1982; Schnegg and Bernard 1996), I eliminated 19 concepts with uniformly low centrality (analysis described below) across countries, resulting in 52 concepts. I then defined what constitutes a tie between two concepts as co-occurring within a text window (Danowski 1982) of five words in the same sentence. Then, I built semantic networks from keyword-in-context data sets following Carley (1993, 1997).

sec.title: Network Analytic Procedures
sec.p: To investigate and compare structural properties of the semantic networks, I used multiple network analytic procedures. First, I analyzed the extent of structural similarities of semantic networks between countries using quadratic assignment procedure (QAP) to compute Pearson correlation coefficients between networks’ similarity matrices (Borgatti et al. 2002; Krackhardt 1988).

Second, to identify countries that have relatively more similar structural meaning based on these correlations, I analyzed the QAP correlation matrix through cluster analysis utilizing the tabu algorithm (Borgatti et al. 2002; Wassermann and Faust 1994).

Third, to investigate structural relationships among concepts in a semantic network, I analyzed concepts’ structural equivalences, defined as the extent to which two nodes have similar patterns of ties with other nodes (Wassermann and Faust 1994).

I measured structural equivalences utilizing similarity matrices of node-by-node correlation coefficients (J. Scott 2000; Wassermann and Faust 1994). I then conducted nonmetric multidimensional scaling (MDS) to analyze and represent a continuous (spatial) model of structural equivalences (Borg and Groenen 1997; Wassermann and Faust 1994). MDS solutions represent in geographic space the degree of structural equivalence of concepts: Concepts that are more (or less) structurally equivalent to each other are closer (or more distant; Wassermann and Faust 1994), whereas absolute positions of concepts are arbitrary. In this study, I chose two-dimensional MDS solutions to analyze and represent structural equivalences because goodness-of-fit measures indicated adequate fit (stress levels between .18 and .23) and they allow for parsimonious presentation (Borg and Groenen 1997; Sturrock and Rocha 2000).

To facilitate interpretation of structural patterns among the more influential concepts, I identified the influence of concepts (their effect on shaping meaning; Corman et al. 2002) by calculating network centrality measures for each country’s semantic network. I utilized the eigenvector approach to closeness centrality (Hanneman and Riddle 2005); concepts with higher (or lower) closeness centrality are more (or less) influential in the overall meaning structure. Exploratory MDS analyses focused on a country’s 35 most influential concepts (constituting the top two-thirds of concepts).

The interpretation of structural patterns identified through MDS, a recommended step for identifying structural patterns and interpreting results of quantitative network analyses (Bernard 2005), was elucidated through theoretical sampling of the data (Miles and Huberman 1994). Interpretations about meaning were based on structural patterns and theoretical sampling; a small subset of theoretically sampled data is included in the results section as quotations to place results back into their original context (Bernard 2005). These quotations are individual instances of writing (parole) that demonstrate structural relations at the most concrete level; such instances collectively constitute the system of meaning (langue; Saussure 1959). These in vivo data samples provide clues about rather than summarizing the local meanings of the industry cluster concept. Also, given space limitations, the offered interpretations focused on key aspects of local meanings rather than the full meaning.

sec.title: Institutional Regimes and Local Meaning Structures
sec.p: After local meanings of the selected concept were mapped onto semantic networks, I explored relationships between local meaning structures and associated institutional logics. In Table 3 , I report QAP correlation coefficients of these associations.

caption.p: QAP-Pearson’s Correlation Coefficients of Semantic Networks

fn.p: Note. Correlations are based on QAP with 5,000 permutations.

sec.p: These results show that the networks of Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States are correlated significantly (p < .01) with each other, with coefficients ranging from r = .24 (Australia with United States) to r = .58 (United Kingdom with Canada). The semantic networks of Austria, Germany, and Switzerland are correlated significantly (p < .01) with each other, with coefficients ranging from r = .25 (Germany with Switzerland) to r = .37 (Austria with Germany). Put differently, the networks of all liberal countries are correlated with each other, as are the networks of all state–corporate countries. Therefore, it appears that similarity of meaning between countries is related to whether they share an overarching institutional logic.

In addition, the network of Austria is correlated significantly (p < .01) with those of Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom (r = .38, r = .31, and r = .27); and the network of Switzerland is weakly correlated significantly (p < .05) with those of Australia and Canada (r = .17 and r = .23). The remaining correlations are not significant. Given that some correlations between liberal and state–corporate countries are significant, an additional layer of similarities may transgress boundaries of overarching logics. Overall, these results suggest that the structural meanings of the industry cluster concept share similarities and differences along institutional boundaries, with some additional cross-boundary similarities.

To further interpret these correlations, I applied cluster analysis utilizing the tabu algorithm. This resulted in a best-fit solution (fit = .16) dividing the countries into four clusters: (1) Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and United Kingdom; (2) Austria and Germany; (3) United States; and (4) Switzerland. The solitary position of the United States (with other liberal countries forming a cluster) may reflect that its form of liberalism is somewhat distinct and has been argued to be the purest form of the liberal model (Jepperson 2002; Jepperson and Meyer 1991). Similarly, Switzerland’s relatively idiosyncratic position may reflect that its state–corporate logic is somewhat distinct and has been argued to be a special variant of state–corporatism with liberal elements (Katzenstein 1984; Kriesi 1982). In sum, it appears that similarities of meaning structures as mapped onto semantic networks between countries reflect both sharing an overarching institutional regime and variations of these ideal types.

Additionally, these clusters indicating similarities in meaning may also reflect cultural and political relationships among countries. Four liberal countries forming a cluster may be related to their sharing a common colonial history and being formally linked through existing Commonwealth institutions—Commonwealth nations have an extensive history of borrowing policies from each other (Leichter 1983). And Switzerland’s relatively dissimilar meaning structure may be related to its long history of isolationist policies (Katzenstein 1984), including not joining the European Union. Hence, being more integrated into a shared political arena—an important institutional force (Fligstein and Stone Sweet 2002)—might contribute to similarities in meaning among countries, along with shared logics.

sec.title: Interpretations of Local Meanings
sec.p: After investigating the degrees of similarity and difference between the meaning structures as mapped onto semantic networks, I explored the nature of structural patterns that indicate the local meanings and interpreted the results of network analytical procedures by exploring the kinds of local meanings of the concept across institutional fields and regimes. I explore four institutional meaning systems drawn from the four clusters I found and present key aspects of these meanings. For the groups including more than one country, I present Austria as the one closest to ideal-typical state–corporatism (Katzenstein 1987; Lehmbruch 1982) and the United Kingdom as the country of origin of the liberal regime (Jepperson 2002; Jepperson and Meyer 1991). This is not to say that clusters of multiple countries represent a homogeneous group.

MDS results of the four selected countries provide continuous spatial models of structural equivalences among influential concepts; the associated plots are presented in Figures 1–4.4 To highlight some key differences in local meanings, I focus my presentation and interpretation of results on structural positions of key actor concepts. I indicate network concepts in italics. As discussed above, I vivify the structural analyses results with a subset of theoretically sampled qualitative data presenting clues of meaning in their original context (Bernard 2005; Miles and Huberman 1994).

sec.title: Austria—Industry Clusters as Formalized Cooperation Projects of Private Interest Government
sec.p:
In the meaning structure of Austria (Figure 1), university, speak|say|tell, competition, and advantage(ous) are relatively structurally nonequivalent; hence, these concepts fulfill relatively distinct roles in the meaning structure. Interestgroup 5 is highly structurally equivalent to cluster, suggesting that industry clusters are intimately related to the peak associations and have become intertwined with state–corporatism’s logic of private interest government (W. R. Scott and Meyer 1991; Streeck and Schmitter 1985). Major Austrian peak associations—the Chambers of Business, Labor, and Agriculture, and the Trade Union Federation (Tàlos and Kittel 1996)—are heavily involved in organizing industry cluster initiatives, where corporations are combined (hence, perhaps, the close collocation of corporation and combine) through (often formal) membership in clusters. Quotes below illustrate (1) how chambers are an integral part of clusters; and (2) how labor interest groups demand participation in industry clusters analogous to that a company’s employees are granted by law in Austria (Karlhofer 1996), pinpointing the local corporatist version of meaning of the concept:
Even after the planned independence of the [automotive] cluster starting with July, the coordinating industry cluster-council should remain. Representatives of provincial politics, interest groups such as chambers of labor and commerce, and representatives of leading industrial enterprises convene in this forum (Der Standard [daily newspaper, Vienna, Austria], May 15, 1999)
Union and Chamber of Labor zero in on the automobile industry cluster. Union and Chamber of Labor demand more influence in the Styrian automobile cluster—up to a central works council. (Wirtschaftsblatt [daily newspaper, Vienna, Austria], December 3, 1998) Whereas competition is highly structurally nonequivalent, cooperation is relatively highly structurally equivalent with several concepts including region, plan|strategy, provide, success(ful). Cooperation appears to be a core element of meaning of industry cluster in Austria, as the following quotes illustrate:

Styria has contrived its provincial promotion of economic development. Special attention is given to the promotion of cooperation. Thus a jumpstart from the province is given during the formation of clusters. (Wirtschaftsblatt, August 20, 2002)
In the strategic program Upper Austria 2000+ cooperation within industrial complexes (clusters) was formulated as the main focus. (Der Standard, May 8, 2001) The role of cooperation in the meaning of industry cluster is reflective of the state–corporate logic, which relies more on cooperation and interest intermediation between economic actors than on competition (Tàlos and Kittel 1996); Austrian industrial policy has a tradition of focusing on regional cooperation among businesses and regional institutions (Katzenstein 1984).

Edagency and government are highly structurally equivalent; change and provide are located relatively close to them. This is an indication that in Austria formal industry cluster projects are frequently initiated—reflecting change—by federal or regional government bodies in coordination with regional economic development agencies, as illustrated by the quote below:
Hence Eco Plus [edagency] works together with the administrative office for technology of the Lower Austrian government. Eco Plus oversees the cooperation network, the administrative office oversees technology development. “The shared management of the cluster is a continuation of the excellent cooperation between the provinces Vienna and Lower Austria”, emphasized member of provincial government Ernest Gabmann. (Austria Presse Agentur [national news agency, Vienna, Austria], July 19, 2001)
University occupies a structurally relatively nonequivalent position; qualitative samples indicate that higher education institutions in the meaning structure signify infrastructural elements of the formalized cluster initiatives, providing society and thus industry with education and expertise. This relationship between educational institutions and industry is consistent with the strong—publicly financed—vocational education system characteristic of Austria and Germany (P. Scott and Kelleher 1996). The quote below illustrates this relationship:

In addition to the targeted promotion of cooperation, the creation of a supporting educational infrastructure takes a particularly high importance for the formation of clusters. In Austria, much has happened in this direction, not least through the creation of universities of applied science. (Der Standard, January 13, 2000) Essential aspects of meaning of industry clusters in Austria can be summarized as state–corporate projects of sanctioned cooperation initiated by a strong state in coordination with regional development agencies and intertwined with corporatist peak organizations constituting an expression of private interest government.

sec.title: United Kingdom —Industry Clusters as Delegated Economic Development Domains
sec.p:
MDS analysis for the United Kingdom (Figure 2) show that cluster is highly structurally equivalent to corporation, nation, important, and begin; initiating industry clusters appears to be considered important at the national level. Government is relatively structurally nonequivalent, which, together with the quotes below, signals a specific, bounded function: providing initial funds for industry cluster initiatives and infrastructure investments. Apart from this basic function, in liberalist tradition—where government’s exercise of authority by interfering into the economy is not welcome (Jepperson 2002)—government devolves much of its authority to other actors.
He [former government minister] hoped that the Government and the European Union could offer financial incentives for the creation of a maritime industry cluster. “Once established, it would have a momentum of its own,” he said. (The West Briton [weekly newspaper, Truro, UK], April 27, 2000)
[B]usiness clusters fulfill a need. Recognising their economic value, the UK government is providing financial support for clusters through the DTI and Regional Development Agencies (RDAs) [edagency]. But while extra help is always appreciated, interference is not. (Director [monthly magazine, London, UK] July 1, 2004)
Edagency is highly structurally equivalent to development and plan|strategy and to grow, create, characterize, promote, and success(ful). In the meaning of industry clusters in the United Kingdom, economic development agencies appear to fill an important role in development, strategy making, and growth of industry clusters, and collectively in the cluster movement.

Responsibility for most industry “clusters” and sectors will be devolved to local enterprise companies (LECs) [edagency], which will enjoy greater financial flexibility. Scottish Enterprise Edinburgh and Lothian [edagency] will take responsibility for two clusters: … Nine other LECs will be responsible for one industry cluster each, while Scottish Enterprise will take control over the biotechnology and digital media sectors. (Director [monthly magazine, London, UK] July 1, 2004)
Edagency in the United Kingdom is not highly structurally equivalent to government (unlike in Austria) or to corporation (unlike in the United States—discussed below). Edagency was most influential in the semantic networks of the United Kingdom and Austria6; however, edagency occupies very different structural positions in their semantic networks. In the United Kingdom, economic development agencies appear to take jurisdiction and authority over clusters, whereas in Austria they appear to organize industries in close coordination with government and peak associations. These differences in meaning juxtapose the United Kingdom’s liberalist devolution of public authority into society and Austria’s state–corporatist strong state intertwined with private interest government.

The structural positions of competition and cooperation pinpoint another difference in meaning between Austria and the United Kingdom. In the United Kingdom’s meaning system, cooperation and competition are highly structurally equivalent, reflecting, as the quotes below illustrate, the focus on stimulating competition that coexists with and is supplemented by cooperation. This mirrors the United Kingdom’s liberal institutional logic of creating efficiency through competition, while also protecting businesses from the risks of unchecked competition (Dobbin 1994b).
The location of similar companies in an area is not enough to generate a self-sustaining cluster effect in which competition is stimulated […]. (Financial Times [daily newspaper, London, UK], April 25, 2001)
There is the need to modify competition with collaboration; to foster regional industrial clusters. (The Guardian [daily newspaper, London, UK], October 19, 1992) In contrast, in Austria, competition is relatively structurally nonequivalent, suggesting, along with the quotes below, that it primarily carries the meaning of an (international or external) threat that regions and corporations can cope with through fostering collaboration in the form of industry clusters. As discussed above, strategic regional cooperation is the nurtured way of relating in Austria, while competition is a necessity to cope with externally induced challenges.

“This [the industry cluster initiative] is Styria’s response to globalization”, explained Paierl [government]. Through industry clusters a region makes itself fit for international competition. (Die Presse [daily newspaper, Vienna, Austria], August 6, 1997)
The organization of areas of economic strengths in form of “clusters” was a politico-economic success story of Austria in the 90’s. The bundling of the limited competitive strength of medium-sized and small enterprises gave rise to: … more successful dealings with difficult export markets, consolidation of regions’ quality as industrial location, and generally the promotion of cooperative not only single-business entrepreneurial thinking. (Austria Presse Agentur, March 8, 2001) These meaning differences regarding competition and cooperation, opposing alternatives to accomplish social order (North 1990), reflect differences in these countries’ long-standing institutional logics.

Returning to the United Kingdom, university is relatively structurally equivalent with build, attract, and obtain, but no actor concepts. University appears to signify an autonomous source of knowledge that could provide the impetus for entrepreneurial growth and industry clusters, as illustrated by the quotes below. These clues of meaning illustrate the liberalist tradition of diffused and limited government authority and the liberalist rationalized belief that entrepreneurial spirit is the main spring of economic growth (Dobbin 1994b).
“The key part is the quality of the university or medical centre. … Clusters grow up around a university that is at the cutting edge of science.” Or to put it another way, the new industries run on brainpower and will form where there are large reserves of their key raw material, world-class thinkers. (The Independent [daily newspaper, London, UK], June 2, 1999)
We are already moving from centrally administered R and D policies to the encouragement of local technology transfer between universities and companies and the development of regional clusters of specialisms–encouraging the growth of the knowledge-based company and the business friendly university. (Government News Network (GNN) [government press agency, London, UK], March 31, 2003) Key aspects of meaning of industry cluster in the United Kingdom appear to be devolution of government authority to regional economic development agencies, encouraging competition supplemented by cooperation, and expectations from the government to provide infrastructural funding for industry-cluster projects to stimulate entrepreneurial activity and wealth generation.

sec.title: United States —Industry Clusters as Projects of Weak State and Strong Corporations
sec.p:
For the United States (Figure 3), cluster is relatively structurally equivalent to corporation and to a lesser degree to edagency. Corporation and edagency are highly structurally equivalent, reflecting the dominant position of firms in the governance and organization of economic activity (Herrigel 1994); this is in contrast to the meaning structures of Austria (where relatively high structural equivalence of edagency and government indicates how a strong state directly shapes economic activity) and the United Kingdom (where edagency is not highly structurally equivalent with actor concepts, indicating their jurisdiction and authority in development, growth, and strategy of industry clusters). It is consistent with U.S. ideology that when the economy requires initiative, corporations will spearhead it (Edmonds 1983); the quote below illustrates this close relationship between economic development agencies and corporations:
But this year, business leaders and economic development officials began discussing a concentrated effort to develop an industry cluster. Enterprise Florida, the state’s main economic development agency, caught wind of what was being discussed. The agency liked what it heard and, last month, it formed the Florida Financial Services Cluster Initiative, with Cohen [JPMorgan executive] at the helm. (Tampa Tribune [daily newspaper, Tampa, FL, USA], September 26, 2003)
Government and university are highly structurally equivalent to each other, and, to a lesser extent, to cooperation and public. This element of meaning reflects cooperation between universities and government agencies in implementing industry cluster initiatives. The quotes below illustrate that government agencies utilize universities’ expertise and knowledge to help form economic development initiatives and cluster projects, thereby mediating their industrial policy through universities:

Purdue University will receive $2 million in federal funds as part of the energy bill to support corn-based fuel research. Officials said the money will help its efforts to provide core technologies for a biobased chemical industry cluster in the Midwest. (The News Sentinel [Fort Wayne, IN, USA], December 8, 2003)
Meanwhile [Governor] McGreevey last week signed an executive order creating Innovation Zones-three industry clusters centered around the state’s public research universities. The aim is to create a so-called innovation triangle, or partnership involving the universities, hightech companies and state government. (NJBIZ [weekly magazine, Somerset, NJ, USA], September 13, 2004) It appears that universities’ key role in the meaning system is to serve as intermediaries in the indirect approach to public policy in the United States. This may represent a weak state’s shaping of private enterprise through indirect, normative means (Dobbin 1994b; Dobbin and Sutton 1998).

Interestgroup occupies a structural position between government and university (and public) on one hand, and corporation and edagency on the other. This reflects that interest groups in this country primarily are political organizations that mobilize and represent interests of business vis-à-vis state and public to influence industries’ environments through lobbying and public relations campaigns (Staber 1985), as the quote below reflects:
Local high-tech industry clusters have reaped benefits from past public relations efforts, but they must do more in the future, area PR professionals were told yesterday. “PR is really a big part of what we’re doing” […] “It’s been a huge factor in gaining support from the state Legislature.” Hagen, co-chair of the Information Technology Association of Southern Arizona [interestgroup], said that industry clusters […] can be difficult for elected officials and the public to understand. (Arizona Daily Star [daily newspaper, Tucson, AZ, USA], March 28, 2001) In sum, key elements of meaning of industry cluster in the United States are indicated by the prevalence of corporate interests in economic organizing and indirect influence of the government through agenda setting and legislation under economic development policy in a manner that is characteristic of a weak state.

sec.title: Switzerland—Liberal Corporatism and Industry Clusters as Organic Phenomenon
sec.p:
In the meaning structure in Switzerland, the only relatively influential actor concepts are corporation and university (Figure 4). Corporation is located in a relatively close position to cluster, along with grow, and is relatively proximal to create. Cluster is relatively structurally equivalent to region and the actions grow and perceive, which suggests a meaning of industry clusters as growth of businesses in a region. In fact, the first two quotes below illustrate that industry cluster refers to the actual phenomenon of industries’ agglomeration in certain locales as a decidedly “natural” development, without active implementation of industry cluster policy initiatives. The third quote communicates a meaning of industry clusters as initiatives to be taken with caution and skepticism.
Industries locate preferably in a cluster, as they are called, of their sector. This refers to regions, in which the sector is concentrated. There, the selection of specialists is larger. (Sonntagszeitung [weekly newspaper, Zurich, Switzerland], February 27, 2005)
Philippe Poindron, president of the BioValley Central Association in Strasbourg, emphasized that in the formation of an industry cluster not only do the scientific and economic interests have to be in the foreground, but also the cultural values need to be taken into account. The development of a cluster would have to take place from below (“bottom-up”) rather than being dictated from above through politics. (Basler Zeitung [daily newspaper, Basel, Switzerland], October 15, 2003)
Laurent-Dominique Piveteau of ETH Lausanne [university] and representative of BioAlpes of the Arc Lémanique weighed in that geography had to be taken into consideration. Meta-clusters yes, but not at any price. Additionally, too heavy cluster formation could erode healthy competition. (Basler Zeitung, October 15, 2003) The qualitative data (including quotes above) suggest that in Switzerland skepticism and resistance toward formal initiatives to manage, grow, or create industry clusters have prevailed, perhaps reflecting industry’s desire to self-govern and its opposition to external interventions, which would be consistent with the liberal capitalist elements of the Swiss corporate regime (Katzenstein 1984; Kriesi 1982). This is in particular contrast to Austria, where formal economic development initiatives are promoted by government and peak associations and executed as top-down models. This contrast is not unexpected, as Austria and Switzerland have a history of foregoing policies that may appear as natural choices across their common border (Katzenstein 1984).

In sum, the first part of the results indicated that similarities of meanings between countries are related to sharing both an overarching logic of organizing and to variations of these ideal types. Further exploration of four variants of local meanings in the second part has provided the tools for interpreting and describing local meaning systems. The insights from these analyses show that the local meaning structures as represented, analyzed, and interpreted in this study conform to what one might expect about discourse in these countries according to our knowledge of different types of institutional regimes.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Advancing methodological approaches to the comparative study of institutional meaning systems is important in a globalizing world, where cultural materials such as concepts and models of organization circulate widely. Guided by a structuralist approach to meaning, I have demonstrated a research design using SNA to map and measure meaning, compare similarities in meaning structures, and interpret structural meaning of a concept derived from a corpus of text. I illustrated this methodological approach using examples of analyzing systems of meaning in local institutional fields as they have become attached to one global keyword (industry cluster), across institutional regimes and countries.

Results suggest that the extent and nature of similarities and differences in meaning are related to whether countries’ local social orders share an overarching institutional logic as well as variations of these ideal types and whether countries belong together to relatively strongly defined cultural reference groups. Because the two groups of countries with state–corporate and liberal regimes in this study also correspond to groups of German- and English-speaking countries, differences in meaning structures might, in part, be a result of differences in language. However, analyses also show important differences among countries within the same language group as well as some similarities of meaning structures across groups. This evidence suggests that findings fundamentally reflect cross-national differences in local meanings of the concept and that the semantic networks effectively captured institutional meaning structures.

Future research utilizing the proposed research design should explore other prominent global concepts and investigate how local meanings are shaped by local institutional arrangements, belonging to more strongly defined cultural reference groups, as well as identifying other contextual factors. Additionally, for the cross-national comparison of meaning of industry clusters, drawing on institutional logics was appropriate. Future applications of the research design could use theories consistent with the substantive area of interest and the nature of comparison.

Several possible future developments of this approach seem promising. Specifically, this study has demonstrated an innovative research design to analyze institutional logics and institutional meaning systems, thus pointing the way to possible theoretical and empirical advances on institutional logics. Building on the presented analyses, future research could explore more detailed country-level relationships as well as cross-national differences in relationships among subsets of institutional logics such as structural differences in the links between actors, actions, and objects of action. Developing research in this direction could concurrently foster theoretical refinements in conceptualizing elements of institutional logics.

Second, qualitative data (text) can be analyzed by quantitative and/or qualitative methods (Bernard 1996); SNA enables both qualitative and quantitative comparative interpretations of meanings of texts, combining strengths of both approaches to explore structural properties underlying large quantities of text as well as producing rich results. A promising direction for SNA would be to develop research designs combining network analyses of textual data with in-depth qualitative analyses to corroborate and support findings of structural properties of meanings. The research design illustrated here thus holds promise for not only independent studies but also multimethod streams of research focused on exploring institutional meaning structures, thereby addressing the emerging issue of developing promising mixed-method designs in the social sciences (Greene 2007).

Finally, every study—qualitative or quantitative—requires researchers to make judgments (Ercikan and Roth 2006). In SNA, identifying and refining themes and concepts sufficiently so they can be applied to an entire corpus of text requires judgments and substantial interpretive analysis; this process does not produce a unique solution (Bernard 1996; Carley 1993; Ryan and Bernard 2000, 2003). While I relied primarily on established semantic categorization schemes to code words into concepts, I decided which concepts to include in the semantic networks as sole researcher; hence, the results of this study should be considered exploratory and illustrative of this research design’s potential. Future applications of this research design may integrate the judgments of multiple coders. Also, future research could expand on the qualitative portion with more comprehensive analyses. Overall, the weight of qualitative (or quantitative) analysis may be increased according to research questions, canons of the discipline, and interests of the researcher.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The author would like to thank Sebnem Cilesiz for her detailed comments on previous drafts of this article, H. Russell Bernard for his developmental feedback and advice, and three anonymous reviewers of Field Methods for their constructive comments.

fn.p: The author declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Context is defined as “the parts of a discourse that surround a word or passage and can throw light on its meaning” (Webster’s 1998).
For a critical analysis of the discursive accomplishments of the industry cluster paradigm, see Greckhamer (2010).
In English, these included the terms “industry/industrial” and “cluster(s)”; in German, they included “industrie/industry” and “cluster(s).”
To increase legibility of these MDS-plots, I omitted points representing the spatial coordinates of concepts; these are located immediately below the center of the label.

Interest groups were found to be influential in the meaning structure in Austria and Germany due to their vital role in the logic of state–corporatism (centrality rank of interestgroup was 11 for Austria and 17 for Germany; for other countries, it ranked from 21 to 42).
Centrality rank of edagency was 9 for Austria and 13 for the United Kingdom, while for other countries it ranged from 29 to 49.
